narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Broad survey of Latinx studies primarily focusing on Latinx experiences in the U.S. I learned about social groups, music styles, activism, foundations of identity, and linguistic analysis of Latinx identity.

the role of latinos in the united states
corporations, government, etc. in creating a latino identity
I gained an in-depth understanding of Latinx history and intertwined impacts of Latinx cultural identity in America.
A survey course covering various topics of Latinx history and dynamics through media, society, literature, etc. and how that has influenced the Latinx community within the United States today
Learned about a range of topics within Latinx studies.

-how race is socially constructed, especially when it comes to Latine people 
-the history and implications of Latinx/a/o/@/e
-latin music
-the marketing of latinidad
-how to look at cultural objects critically and write about them academcially

This course is a very broad overview of Latinx studies with a dominate lens of cultural analysis, which makes sense given that it is Laguna teaching it. There is some historical and theoretical grounding, though most of the class is spent engaging with cultural productions like movies, art, works of fiction, in addition to some more academic cultural studies sources.
This course mostly focuses on Latine people and their experiences (as opposed to Latin America as a region).

inquiring the basics of the interdisciplinary field of Latinx studies, from defining labels and terms to knowing the history of Latinx communities and cultural productions; how to critically read a secondary/research article; how to think about capitalism and race in US society; how to think about 'natural' disasters and human-made disasters in history
A broad overview of U.S influence on the issues within Latin America today as well as dissecting Latinidad in general.
I learned a lot about the political, economic, and social history of Latinx communities.
I was able to think critically about the material presented to me; truly analyze primary sources; apply the material to the greater community around me at home and at Yale, etc.

I learned more surrounding the Latinx population in the United States, and their depiction in media. There was a wide variety of mediums, from music to novels. A skill that I improved on during that time was writing. Also, I enjoyed the class and it was one of the only opportunities for me to actually learn about the Latinx diaspora.
I learned a lot about how Latin Americans fit into the United States culturally. I learned how to analyze a research article.

An incredibly rich survey of the major components of Latinx studies. The varied nature of the three essays gave lots of opportunity for growth in different styles of writing, including evaluating peer reviewed research, analyzing cultural objects like film and music, and more. Just an amazing and well rounded course.
Learned more about the nuances of Latinidad and how Latinxs in the United States have been treated throughout history.
a lot of information about the formation and imagination of latinidad in the us.
I learned a base understanding of essential concepts within the field of Latinx studies.
I learned so much about Latin American history, Latinx history, and Latinx culture in the U.S.
Chicanx power!
I learned how to analyze different topics in Latino studies from a variety of formats
General introduction to the past and present histories of the Latinx community both in and out of the United States.

I learned a lot about the relationship different Latinx groups have to the US and to each other. Each week, we went over a different topic in Latinx studies and, by the end of the class, I felt like I had a good understanding of some of what the field has to offer. I also learned how to engage with multiple forms of media and build an argument from the different sources.

Many skills and insights were gained from the course such as critical assess the complicated history between United States and Latin America. Reading cultural works that aided the overall understanding of the relationship between US and Latin America.

This course allowed me to develop new skills necessary to address the effect of racial relations within the Latinx community in the United States and the role the relationship between the US and Latin countries played in the establishment of Latinx identities.  This class also brought me new insights into the structure and reality of Latinx culture in the US today and how its evolution was affected and guided by politics, social issues, and so much more.
A better understanding of what Latinx studies is and the possibilities within the field.
I learned about Latinx culture throughout the years, and how to think critically about different sociological/historical theories.

By taking this course, I've learned how to fully engage in discussions regarding cultural collectives. I've also learned about various social theories regarding colonialism and the nineteenth century imperialist project.
I learned how to closely analyze a piece of media/artistic text.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: great content, passionate professor, great TF; Weaknesses: engagement could have been higher - sometimes the class got repetitive in structure

strengths: great course for latino students, relatable
weaknesses: too many readings that did not always correlate with assignments
Strengths: broad scope, engaging readings and discussion

Strengths: Covered a variety of topics to cater to many interests, informative lectures, great reading selections
Weakness: None
Readings are great.

I wish we had talked more about Latinx history and less about high-level terms and definitions and literary analysis. I wanted to hear more about US involvement in Latin America and about the Chicanx movement, for example. At times this class felt like a class on literary analysis.

THIS IS A GREAT CLASS! It's wonderfully designed and gives you a real preview into lots of interesting topics in Latinx Studies, allows you to explore based on your personal interests, and exposes you to cool ideas and figures you might not be aware of. A real strength in its design is that students who don't speak Spanish don't feel excluded. 

One note: I would have love to revisit Latine characters from my Disney childhood in this class!

This class is very accessible. Its concepts are not difficult to grasp, but that isn't to say that you have have profound moments of discovery along the way if you put in the work. It could be improved by some more cohesion between the weeks. While we can only cover so much ground between all of Latin America/Latinx studies, it would be helpful to know why there's a focus on Mexico, Cuba, and Puerto Rico throughout the course. These nationalities may have the largest numbers of Latinx people, but I still wonder if more variety could be included in this respect.

Strengths: The course covers such a wide array of topics.
Weaknesses: Sometimes its hard to find the readings that Professor Laguna doesnt provide on Canvas.

strengths - syllabus is well-structured with assignments, TAs are great, topics covered are great 
weaknesses - music unit should be integrated throughout the course or at the beginning rather than at the end, since more detailed knowledge of dembow/reggae would have been helpful for some people who did assignment 1 based on music
Strengths is that it is an interesting and engaging lecture. All of the readings are also very relevant. The final paper prompt was a little too broad however.
No weaknesses. Strengths: engaging lectures, interesting and manageable assignments, helpful TAs, clear structure to class and chronology of lectures, etc.

strengths: Professor Laguna, the set up of the course, the amount of support offered by TAs, the TAs themselves, the timing of the assignments, the engagement with the course 

weaknesses: none

The strength of the course is the material. It is very interesting at times. I especially enjoyed the Disney movie and the presentation on Central America and  the social movements. The weaknesses of the course could be that some topics seem to deserve more time, but besides that, everything was great.

Strength is that it is very engaging and offers a perspective we dont hear much. A weakness is that I think it focuses too much on Puerto Rico, and I wish there was more emphasis on other parts of Latin America. I understand it is a survey course, but one of the four days dedicated to Puerto Rico could have been a lecture on other regions.

Strengths: lots of readings to thoroughly engage with each subject and get to know the literature around it. A good mix of fiction and nonfiction. Well-developed lectures

Weaknesses: slides or recordings of the lecture should have been sent out to everyone.
The slides are crammed with information that is sometimes unnecessary.

This was one of my favorite courses ever at Yale. It was incredibly human and engaging thanks to Professor Laguna, especially as a Latino student. The breadth of the course would make it very easy to feel like specificity and critical evaluation of any one subject was sacrificed, but Professor Laguna made every lecture feel detailed and rich.

Strengths: Professor Laguna is an AMAZING lecturer. He always makes sure to be engaging in his lecture and includes a variety of ways of lecturing. Moreover, the readings for this course are super interesting and vary. 
Weaknesses: The one weakness I will say this course has was that sometimes some topics were quickly brushed over. I wish we were able to cover topics such as Central America and Brown Power for more than one or two classes. Additionally, I felt that the three books that were assigned to us to read were not all too effective and it would have been better to just assign a selected chapter.
lectures should be recorded, ir slides should at least be posted.
A strength is professor Laguna who is a prepared and great lecturer who makes the class a great intro course.
The course material for this class is excellent. It is really interesting and fun, even for people who are familiar with Latinx history and current events.
ASSIGN READINGS BY ACTUAL INDIGENOUS LATINX SCHOLARS !!
Comprehensive history about Latinx contestations and political struggle
Very engaging course especially with Albert Laguna!! My only gripe is that we didnt have access to the slides so it was difficult to organize what I have learned.

One of the strengths of this course was the breadth of histories that we covered about the different communities under the Latinx umbrella. Although this came at the expense of the amount of time spent on each topic, it was a wonderful introduction to Latinx studies. I also loved that we got to read some literature and watch movies, in addition to reading journal articles.

Strengths: It covers a wide range of topics, so there is something interesting for everyone. There is a good mix of materials to learn from, from ads to movies to personal essays.

Weaknesses: The readings, especially towards the end of the semester, were long.
Lecture classes provided a lot of information within a short period of time. The TA was helpful. The professor tried to make the classroom engaging by utilizing unique methods.

I absolutely loved this class and nothing comes up when I am thinking of a critique. The course itself, however, does have many strengths.  The Professor consistently maintained the lecture's attention and it was an amazing course for Latinx-identifying students.  I also appreciate the course's use of sources outside literature and written work.
Strengths: draws from a number of disciplines, great organization of class content
It was very interesting and had a good pace.

The biggest strength was definitely how smart Prof Laguna and the teaching staff were. They had so many interesting insights that even "basic" lectures were fascinating. I was always sad at the end of our 50 minute lectures because I just wanted to keep hearing what they had to say about the topic we were covering for that day. That kind of leads into a weakness, though. As a survey course, we covered a ton of different topics, but our lectures would seem a bit rushed since we only had 2 classes max to cover most topics. I can't really blame anyone for this but I do wish we could've had more time for the individual topics.

This course is laid out perfectly from beginning to end and the lectures are neatly set up in chronological order. I enjoyed the historical context discussed within each class. We covered a lot of literature in the last few weeks and in the future, I would recommend spending more time on each piece rather than skimming over the literature.
The books given to read were too long in the time frame given to do so.

one strength -- sections; definitely give more time to deeply consider readings and context behind them as well as to look at other helpful materials such as music videos, interviews etc. I think offering even more suggested texts would also be helpful.
weakness -- I think lectures could be a little more diverse in terms of regions. Though a survey course on Latinx history in the U.S., I was left wondering about the role (even if peripheral) of other Latin American groups within the U.S. outside the core four that seemed to be the focus of this course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're interested in Latinx studies, definitely! If you're like me and you're taking this class to fulfill a requirement for another major, this might be too broad for you, although I'd ask the professor.
yes!! overall, great course, especially for latino students

I would recommend this course to any student who is in ERM. The class is a great beginner class for those who are curious about ERM topics but don't know where to start. Simultaneously, it is also great for people who more advanced in their ERM learning because it facilitates great conversation and further thinking.
Absolutely, if you have any interest in learning about the Latinx community or culture this is 100% the class for you
Yes, great class
Yes.
YES. DO IT.
Please take this class! It's such a great course and you'll learn a lot

Yes! It might be a bit repetitive if you've taken lots of Latinx studies/ER&M/etc. classes, but even if you have you'll learn something new from this class  if not from a different perspective. Again, there's a focus on cultural productions that you might not get elsewhere from other Yale faculty.

YES, I definitely would recommend this class. The class covers such a wide array of topics, from history to music, so theres something for everyone. Even if you arent interested in Latinx Studies, I would recommend taking the class just to experience having Professor Laguna as a lecturer.
yes! lectures are super great and interactive, readings outside of class and the stuff we watch and analyze during lecture are phenomenal
Yes. It is a great intro course that you will enjoy and learn from.
Yes! Really interesting and super manageable to balance with other courses and extracurriculars
Absolutely; whether or not the student is Latinx, this course is a great introduction to the culture, politics, society, etc. of Latin America, and Latinx people in the United States.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It was extremely interesting as I got to learn more about media representation, race, and the Latinx diaspora in the United States. Professor Laguna is very passionate and the lectures are almost always interesting.
Take this class. Please. Especially if you are Latin American. I cannot recommend it enough, it was the highlight of my semester. One of the most fun classes you will ever take.

YES!!! This course is so amazing and Professor Laguna is truly the best. Especially as a Latino, you get to learn so much more about the hidden ways that Latines have been marginalized and learn about movements of resistance as well. Overall, a class that you will not regret taking and it. has assignment that are not too hard.
yes its very interesting and important. however feedback on essays isnt very useful and grades dont always make sense.
Yes, if they do not have much of a background in the field of ethnic studies or Latinx studies this is a great intro course that goes over the basics.
Yes! If you're at all interested in the topic, the class is excellent. it is really well organized and the material is great, as is Professor Laguna.
Yes, especially if they identify as Latinx

Absolutely!! It was an eye-opening experience taking this course and it was my first time learning about important topics such as the Puerto Rican debt crisis and the formation and criticism of labels such as Latino/a, Latine, Latinx, etc. Definitely would consider!
Yes, you should definitely take this course! It has a very manageable work lecture, the TFs are amazing, and lecture is very engaging.
I would recommend it. I feel like everyone can learn something from the class. Its also engaging.
Yes! Its a great course for anyone looking for something not only interesting but that allows you to use the course to research other topics you want to explore outside the syllabus or in more depth
Yes! Need to see if this is something they enjoy.

I would recommend this class to other Yale students.  I think this class was refreshing because it allowed students to interact with sources that were not the regular written readings but instead brought in multimedia readings.  I also believe the student discussion sections were eye-opening and allowed students to discuss and interact with the concepts at hand and how they connect or shape today.
Yes! My favorite class this semester. Professor Laguna makes this lecture so engaging and the readings and topics covered give a taste of different possibilities within Latinx Studies.
Yes. It has a great curriculum and all the TAs were amazing.

Yes, I would recommend taking this course to those interested in Latinx history, social movements, and experiences. This class does a great job of drawing from historical events and discussing the implications that these events have had on the Latinx collective. The professor also does a great job of emphasizing the diverse political and social agendas within the Latinx community.
Yes! Everyone should take this course.
I would recommend this course to someone who has never really learned anything about Latinx history.
Yes!! I absolutely loved this class and was always excited to go to class. One of the few classes at Yale that I actually enjoyed.
